item.title: 47 Basic Strongman: Week 5 Day 2
item.description: Lower Day Squats Pause at the bottom for one second. Work up to a 1RM over seven sets. Warmup 135x10 185x5 Work 225x1 275x1 315x1 345x1 365x1 375x1 385x1 385lbs for one is certainly a paused PR. But, I think I could have gone heavier. It was right around 9 or 9.5 RPE. Given my recent track record of failing top sets it’s probably better that I didn’t make a heavier attempt.

item.title: 46 Basic Strongman: Week 5 Day 1
item.description: Upper Day Close Grip Bench Press Work up to 1RM over seven sets. Pause at the bottom for one second. 45x10 95x5 185x1 195x1 205x1 215x1 225x1 235x1 245x1 (Pretty sure this is a PR) 245x1 definitely felt like a true 1RM. I changed my approach to these seven sets compared to last time. The warmups that I had been including are now separate sets so that the seven can be closer jumps.

item.title: 45 Basic Strongman: Week 4 Day 3
item.description: Farmers and Sandbag Load Day Farmers Walk Lap is 40ft with turn then a drop. Final set finish with hold ALAP. 100x4 (lowered starting wait compared to last time.) 160x2 195x1 PR Sandbag Load This was planned to be a seated row day. But, since last week’s sandbag went so poorly I decided to revisit the sandbag today. Warmup 85x5 5 Minute EMOM 206x2 PR 206x2 206x1 (gassed out.

item.title: 44 Basic Strongman: Week 4 Day 2
item.description: Lower Day Front Squats Work up to a 2RM over seven sets. I was also supposed to pause these for 1 second. I didn’t. I forgot about until just now. 45x10 135x5 195x2 235x2 255x2 275x2 285x2 (PR) 18” Deadlift Work up to a 3RM over 5 sets. 135x3 225x3 315x3 405x3 445x3 (PR)

item.title: GitHub Pages and Quakkels.com
item.description: So I must’ve been under a rock for the last 21 months because it wasn’t until this week that I learned that GitHub Pages now supports SSL certificates for custom domains. They’ve had SSL support since 2016 for sites using {user}.github.io domains. But it has also been available for custom domain sites (like this one) since May of 2018. Before the feature was upgraded there were hacks to get around the custom domain limitation.

item.title: 43 Basic Strongman: Week 4 Day 1
item.description: Upper Day Paused Close Grip Incline Bench Pause at bottom for one second. Work up to a 2RM over seven sets. 45x10 95x5 135x3 175x2 195x2 200x2 205x1 (Missed second rep) Axle Strict Press Clean first rep. Work up to a 3RM over 4 sets. 140x3 155x3 165x3 180x2 (Missed final rep) Need to do a better job of selecting top sets. Would preffer to have all reps succeed than to reach and miss.

item.title: 42 Basic Strongman: Week 3 Day 3
item.description: Farmers and Sandbag Load Day Farmer Walks Lap is 40ft with turn then a drop. Final set finish with hold ALAP. 120lbs/hand for 4 laps. 160lbs/hand for 2 laps. 190lbs/hand for 1 lap. Held for 6 breathes. Sandbag Loading I wanted to use my new 100KG Cerberus Sandbag V2 for this workout. The sandbag I used last time was only 167lbs. I filled the new sandbag to 206lbs.

item.title: RSS Discovery Engine
item.description: RSS Discovery Engine was a fun project intended to encourage the use of RSS feeds. You can find the code on GitHub or try it out.

item.title: 41 Basic Strongman: Week 3 Day 2
item.description: Lower Day Squats Work up to a 2RM over seven sets. One second pause at the bottom. 135x10 185x5 225x2 275x2 315x2 345x2 365x2 This might’ve been an RPE8.5. 2” Deficit Deadlift Decided not to do touch’n’go reps this week because I use bumpers and deficit deads are a pretty new movement pattern for me. Work up to a 3RM over 5 sets. 135x3 225x3 315x3 365x3 375x3 Felt like a REP9.

item.title: 40 Basic Strongman: Week 3 Day 1
item.description: Pressing Day Close Grip Paused Bench Work up to a 2RM over 7 sets. Pause each rep for one second at bottom. 45x10 95x5 135x3 185x2 205x2 220x2 235x2 Log Strict Press Work up to 3RM over 4 sets. 100x3 125x3 150x3 170x3

item.title: 39 Basic Strongman: Week 2 Day 3
item.description: Farmers and Cable Rows Day Farmer Walks Lap is 40ft with turn then a drop. Final set finish with hold ALAP. 110lbs/hand for 4 laps. 150lbs/hand for 2 laps. 185lbs/hand for 1 lap. Held for 4 breathes. Seated One Arm Rows Alternating arms 45x5 90x5 105x5 110x5 115x5 These seated rows felt great. I should’ve made this pulley system a lot sooner.

item.title: 38 Basic Strongman: Week 2 Day 2
item.description: Lower Day Front Squats Work up to a 3RM over seven sets. Pause one second in the hole. 45x10 135x5 185x3 225x3 245x3 255x3 275x3 PR!!! 18” Deadlift 135x5 225x5 315x5 405x5 425x5 PR!!!

item.title: 37 Basic Strongman: Week 2 Day 1
item.description: Pressing Day Close Grip Incline Bench One second pause. Work up to a 3RM over seven sets. 45x10 95x5 135x3 165x3 185x3 195x3 (This was an incline PR) 200x0 (skipped this set) Axle Push Press Continental clean first rep. Work up to 5RM over four sets. 100x5 (This was an “extra” set to get used to push pressing and continental cleaning) 140x5 155x5 170x5 180x5 It’s been over a week since I’ve done any rows.

item.title: 36 Basic Strongman
item.description: Farmers and Sandbag Day Farmer Walks Lap is 40 feet with a turn at one end and a drop/re-pick at the other. Final set hold for as long as possible. 100lbs/hand for 4 laps 140lbs/hand for 2 laps 175lbs/hand for 1 lap. Held for 7 breaths. I should be able to go heavier next time since I held them for so long on the last lap. Sandbag Load Load over 52” high bar.

item.title: 35 (Basic Strongman)
item.description: Lower Day Squats Pause for one second. Work up to 3RM over seven sets. 135x10 185x5 225x3 275x3 315x3 335x3 345x3 Felt like I perhaps could’ve gone heavier, but didn’t want to get too ambitious. This is a PR anyway since I’ve never really tried paused squats before. 2” Deficit Deadlift Touch’n’go. Work up to a 5RM over five sets. 135x5 225x5 275x5 315x5 Skipped final set.

item.title: 34 (Basic Strongman)
item.description: Pressing Day Close Grip Paused Bench Work up to three rep max over seven sets 45x10 95x5 135x3 165x3 185x3 205x3 215x3 Log Strict Press Work up to five rep max over four sets. Clean first rep. 100x5 120x5 140x5 160x3 (failed fourth rep) 150x3 (work to make up for missed reps) I’m following the Basic Strongman program from the e-book Built By Mike by Mike Westerling.

item.title: 33 (No Plan)
item.description: No Plan Day Since I’m certainly going to change my program starting next week, I decide to stray from the HLM template that I’ve been following. Today I focused on Farmer Walks and Cable rows. I spent some time rigging up a couple of pulleys to add to my Spud Inc pulley. So now I have a pulldown that is straight vertical, and I can rig it so I have a seated cable row as well.

item.title: 32 (HLM)
item.description: Heavy Day Squats are increasing slowly. Overhead press is increasing slowly. But deadlifts have regressed. I think one heavy set a week and one workout of SLDL 3x5 a week isn’t working. I’m not sure if doing heavy squats in the same workout as heavy deadlifts is too taxing. I might decide to go back a to 4 day split next week. Squats 45x5 135x5 225x5 315x3 330x1 340 for 3 sets of 5 Overhead Press 45x5 95x5 135x3 155x1 162.

item.title: 31 (HLM)
item.description: Medium Day Squats 45x5 135x5 225x5 275x3 295x1 310lbs for 3 sets of 5 Overhead Press 45x5 95x5 135x3 145x1 152.5 lbs for 3 sets of 5 SLDL 205x3 225x5 275x3 285 lbs for 3 sets of 5 Featured Music Best deadlifting (and SLDL) music. “Give me all you have! Pull as hard as you can!”

item.title: 30 (HLM)
item.description: Light Day SSB Squats 45x5 135x5 245x5 275x3 290x1 300lbs for 3 sets of 5 Bench 45x5 135x5 185x3 205x1 215x1 225x5 225x3 185 for 3 sets of 5 Bench didn’t go well today. Maybe this is too heavy for a “light” day. Pendlay Row 135x5 185x3 185x1 205 for 3 sets of 5

item.title: 29 (HLM)
item.description: Heavy Day Skipped over the medium day and went straight to heavy. Redoing the squat session from my last heavy workout to get all 3x5 at 335lbs. Squats 45x5 135x5 225x5 315x3 335 for 3 sets of 5 Overhead Press 45x5 95x5 135x3 155x1 162.5lbs for 5 sets of 3 My arms felt dead today. I could only manage 3 reps in the first set. So I switched to 5x3 instead of 3x5.

item.title: 28 (HLM)
item.description: Light Day SSB Squats 65x5 155x5 245x3 285x1 295 for 3 sets of 5 Bench 45x5 135x5 185x3 215x1 225 for 3 sets of 5 185 for 2 sets of 8 Pendlay Row 135x8 185x4 205x8 205x6 205x6 Rows did not feel good. Need to work those more.

item.title: 27 (HLM)
item.description: Heavy Day I didn’t train much during December. So this workout is a measure of how much I’ve regressed. Squats 45x5 135x5 225x5 315x5 335x5 335x5 335x4 Only had 4 reps in my last set. But I’m pleased I was able to do this with 335. Overhead Press 45x5 95x5 135x3 145x1 155x1 160 for 3 sets of 5 Very pleased that I was able to get these reps with 160 pounds.

item.title: Flat is Better Than Nested Versus Single Entry Single Exit
item.description: As a program ages and receives updates, more and more features are built. Logic is added and the code becomes increasingly more complicated to read and understand. So programmers invent recommended practices to manage the complexity and to preserve the maintainability of their code. The goal being to keep the cognitive load to minimum levels so the programmer can work efficiently. One popular practice is to avoid nested code when possible.

item.title: Functions for Documentation Instead of Comments
item.description: Using good function naming and composition will decrease the need for gratuitous comments and increase your code’s readability. I’ve become convinced that comments are often worth avoiding. Comments aren’t subject to a compiler nor to an interpreter. Code may change and the corresponding comment often remains as it was. Except now the comment is misleading. This makes maintaining the code unnecessarily difficult. Use Function Names to Document Code Consider this code that determines the “Day of the Programmer”.

item.title: Naming Things Clearly
item.description: Clean Code by Robert C. Martin is one of my favorite programming texts. It has a chapter called Meaningful Names wherein principles for the clear and clean naming of code elements are explained. When we write code we should be considering the programmer who follows us. Sometimes it may be ourselves who have not touched the code for months or years. The programmer working in previously written code will need to study it to try and recognize the intention and systems of the original author.

item.title: 26 (HLM)
item.description: Light Day SSB Squats 65x5 155x5 245x3 275x1 285lbs for 3 sets of 5 Close Grip Bench 45x5 95x5 135x5 185x3 205x1 215lbs for 5 sets of 5 The shoulder is just about back to normal. Close grip bench with elbows tucked helped stability a lot. Pendlay Row 135x3 185x3 205lbs for 3 sets of 8

item.title: 25 (HLM)
item.description: Heavy Day Weights felt good today. Feels like I’ve accidentally timed my first workout back after Thanksgiving so that everything felt great. Also, my shoulder didn’t bother me at all today. It’ll be tested in a couple days with bench. Squats 45x5 135x5 225x3 315x3 335x1 345lbs for 3 sets of 5 Overhead Press 45x5 95x5 135x3 150x1 160lbs for 3 sets of 5 Deadlift 225x5 315x3 365x1 405lbs for 1 set of 5

item.title: 24 (HLM)
item.description: Medium Day Squats 45x5 135x5 225x5 275x3 295x1 315 for 3 sets of 5 Overhead Press 45x5 95x5 135x3 145 for 3 sets of 5 Thankfully OHP doesn’t affect my shoulder as much as bench. SLDL 135x5 225x3 275 for 3 sets of 5

item.title: 23 (HLM)
item.description: Light Day Squats 65x5 155x5 245x3 275 for 3 sets of 5 CG Paused Bench 45x5 95x5 135x5 155x3 185 for 5 sets of 5 Shoulder still bothering me. The higher reps, closer grip, and pause made me feel like I was working at least a little bit. Didn’t want to go any heavier because I could definitely ‘feel’ the weight on my shoulder. Pendlay Row 135x5 185x3 200 for 3 sets of 8

item.title: 22 (HLM)
item.description: Today I started a new approach with Heavy/Light/Medium (HLM.) Heavy Day Squats 45x5 135x5 225x5 315x3 325x1 340lbs for 3 sets of 5 Squats were prescribed to be 5x5, but I changed it once the workout was underway because it was taking so long, and it felt heavy. Overhead Press 45x5 95x5 135x3 155x1 157.5lbs for 3 sets of 5 Press was prescribed for 5x5. Decided to change it to 3x5 just like squat.

item.title: 21 (Persistence)
item.description: Bench Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Bench 240 2 3 Pendlay Row 240 2 3 I failed the first rep of my third set. And my left shoulder felt tweaked. Decided to call it a day and not push it.

item.title: 20: R/Strongman Challenge (Persistence)
item.description: R/Strongman Challenge Day (Usually deadlift day) Got an 18” Deadlift gym PR with a lift of 495lbs. Your browser does not support the video tag. Superset Lift LBs Sets Reps SSB Squat 305 4 3 DB Step Up 50 4 6

item.title: 19 (Persistence)
item.description: Overhead Press Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Overhead Press 175 5 3, 3, 3, 2, 3 Lat Pulldown 175 5 6 OHP will be kept at 175 until I can complete all 5 sets of 3 reps. Superset 2 Lift LBs Sets Reps DB Floor Flies 40 4 6 DB Seated Press 50 4 10, 10, 10, 7 Will keep DB Seated Press at 50 until I can complete all 4 sets of 10.

item.title: 18 (Persistence)
item.description: Deadlift Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Squat 345 5 3 Ab Roller bw 5 10 Instead of doing my usual 18” deadlift superset I opted to attempt an entry into r/strongman’s 18” deadlift challenge. Unfortunately, I failed with 495lbs. It broke off the blocks, but I just couldn’t get it past my knees. Might attempt 485 tomorrow or Sunday.

item.title: 17 (Persistence)
item.description: Bench Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Bench 235 5 3 Barbell Row 235 5 3 Superset 2 Lift LBs Sets Reps Axle Press 190 4 3 Isolation DB Curl 35 4 10

item.title: 16 (Persistence)
item.description: Deadlift Day Yay! Day two back on track. Superset 1 Goal was to deadlift 405 for 5 sets of 3. But failed the third rep of the second set and had to back off a bit. Deadlift: 3 at 405lbs, then 2 at 405lbs. Finished with 3 sets of 3 at 395lbs. Superset with… Ab Roller 5 sets of 10 with bodyweight. Superset 2 Lift LBs Sets Reps SSB Squat 295 4 3 DB Step Up 40 4 6 The program is getting heavy enough that I’m removing some of the supplemental work like the Pinch Block and Jumping Jacks.

item.title: 15 (Persistence)
item.description: Overhead Press Day Getting back into the routine this week. Last week amounted to a full 7 days away from the gym. I was starting to feel a little run down anyway. The weights were feeling heavier than they should. So maybe the week off will do some good for my recovery. Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Overhead Press 170 5 3 Lat Pulldown 170 5 6 Ran out of time for the second superset.

item.title: 14 (Persistence)
item.description: Bench Day Conflicts in my schedule have caused me to miss a few days this week. I decided to skip ahead to bench day and modify it pretty heavily from what I usually do. Bench: 230lbs 5x3 Barbell Row: 225lbs for 3. Then 245lbs for 2x3 (PR) I am happy with the rowing. For the last several weeks I’ve used an axle bar. With an axle I end up being limited by grip.

item.title: 13 (Persistence)
item.description: Overhead Press Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Overhead Press 165 5 3 Lat Pulldown 165 5 6 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Didn’t have time to do the second superset.

item.title: 12 (Persistence)
item.description: Squat Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Squat 345 5 3 Ab Roller bw 5 10 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Superset 2 Actually, I didn’t superset. Was feeling so dead at this point that I decided to drop the assistance stuff and only do the 18” deadlifts. Lift LBs Sets Reps 18” Deadlift 415 4 3 415lbs for 3 reps is a PR.

item.title: 11 (Persistence)
item.description: Bench Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Bench 225 5 3 Axle Row 175 5 5 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Superset 2 Lift LBs Sets Reps Axle Press 190 4 3 Isolation DB Curl 35 4 10 50’ DB Suitcase Carry 80 4 1

item.title: 10 (Persistence)
item.description: Deadlift Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Deadlift 385 5 3 Ab Roller bw 5 10 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 These deadlifts felt very heavy. I’m going to watch my protein intake to see if I can continue this block’s linear progression. Though, I might reduce reps down to 2 instead of 3. Or, I might only train deadlifts once every two weeks.

item.title: 9 (Persistence)
item.description: Overhead Press Day Switching it up! Changing up the Persistence program from the first time I ran it. Instead of an upper and lower superset each day, I’m going to have an upper body day with two upper body supersets. Lower body days will have two lower body supersets. This hopefully will be easier to recover from. Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Overhead Press 160 5 3 Lat Pulldown 166 5 6 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Superset 2 Lift LBs Sets Reps DB Floor Fly 35 4 6 Seated DB Press 50 4 8 50’ DB Suitcase Carry 80 4 1

item.title: 8 (Persistence)
item.description: Squat Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Squat 335 5 3 Ab Roller bw 5 8 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Superset 2 Lift LBs Sets Reps Axle Press 190 4 3 Pinch Block 47.5 4 3 DB Lunges 35 4 3 I’ve been liking the unilateral work a lot lately.

item.title: 7 (Persistence)
item.description: Bench Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Bench 220 5 3 Axle Rows 160 5 5 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Superset 2 Lift Lbs Sets Reps 18” Deadlift 405 4 3 DB Isolation Curl 30 4 10 50’ DB Suitcase Carry 80 4 1 I kept the 18” Deadlifts at 405.

item.title: 6 (Persistence)
item.description: Deadlift Day Superset 1 Lift LBs Sets Reps Deadlift Day 375 5 3 Ab Roller bw 5 8 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Deadlifts felt good. I’m really liking the 5x3 scheme. First work set was done without straps for a double overhand PR. Superset 2 Lift Lbs Sets Reps DB Floor Flies 30 4 5 Pinch Block 47.

item.title: 5 (Persistence)
item.description: Overhead Press Day Decided to switch up the set and rep scheme just a little. I’ve been on a calorie deficit for about a week, and I think I’ll be able to keep up with my lifts if I reduce the reps per set, but then increase total sets. Superset 1 Lift Weight Sets Reps Press 155 5 3 Lat Pulldown 155 5 6 Jumping Jacks bw 5 20 Superset 2 Lift Weight Sets Reps SSB Squat 285 4 3 DB Seated Press 50 4 8 50’ DB Suitcase Carry 80 4 1 This new rep/set configuration worked well.

item.title: 4b (Persistence)
item.description: Axle Press Day Superset 1 Lift Weight Sets Reps Axle Press 210 1 2 Axle Press 230 1 1 This workout was just a little make-up day since I had to cut yesterday’s workout short. 210lbs for 2 and 230lbs for 1 are both personal records.

item.title: 4 (Persistence)
item.description: Squat Day Superset 1 Lift Weight Sets Reps Squat 330 3 3 Turkish Get-up 15 3 3 Jumping Jacks bw 3 30 Only had time for one superset today.

item.title: 3 (Persistence)
item.description: Bench Day Superset 1 Lift Weight Sets Reps Bench 215 3 5 Axle Pendlay Row 160 3 8 Jumping Jacks bw 3 30 Superset 2 Lift Weight Sets Reps 18” Deadlift 405 3 3 Isolation DB Curl 30 3 10 50’ DB Suitcase Carry 80 3 2 Today felt really good.

item.title: 2 (Persistence)
item.description: Deadlift Day Superset 1 Lift Weight Sets Reps Deadlift 365 3 5 Ab Roller bw 3 8 Jumping Jacks bw 3 30 Notes: Might adjust this volume on deadlifts. Want to lift heavy, but was really draggin’ after the second round. Superset 2 Lift Weight Sets Reps DB Floor Flies 25 3 5 Pinch Block 45 3 4 One Legged Hip Thrust bw 3 10 Notes: First superset much harder the the second.

item.title: 1 (Persistence)
item.description: Strict Press Day Superset 1 Lift Weight Sets Reps Press 150 3 5 Lat Pulldown 150 2 10 Lat Pulldown 150 1 6 Jumping Jacks bw 3 30 Notes: Reached failure too soon on Lat Pulldown. Keep weight here for next time. Superset 2 Lift Weight Sets Reps SSB Squat 275 2 5 DB Seated Press 40 2 8 50’ Sandbag Carry 165 2 1 Notes: Second superset was interrupted.

item.title: Run Plex on an Ubuntu Server at Home
item.description: Recently I’ve decided that having limited high quality entertainment choices is better than having endless choices that are of questionable quality. So my household decided to end our Netflix subscription. This decision motivated me to build a private streaming media server for our home. Here is how I created a home media server with Plex and a home server tower. Choosing the Media Server There are two popular software options for home media server.

item.title: Getting Started with Mobile Development and Xamarin
item.description: Xamarin enables programmers to write native mobile applications for both Android and iOS using C# and free development tools like Visual Studio Community Edition. This means that if you’re invested in the .NET ecosystem and the C# language, you can write cross-platform mobile applications using technology that’s already familiar to you. A note on development for iOS: You will need a mac in order to build iOS versions of the app.

item.title: Home Gym Outfitting; Train with a Sled
item.description: Outfitting a home gym with a sled for drags and arm-over-arm pulls is simple. You don’t need to spend hundreds of dollars on equipment or gym memberships in order to train with a sled. You also don’t really need any tools or handyman skills to get started. When I first wanted to add arm-over-arm pulls to work my cardio, grip, arms, and back, I looked around and found a few different options.

item.title: Getting Started with Django
item.description: Django is a Python framework that I’ve written about before. I’ve compared Django to ASP.NET MVC. But, I didn’t go into much detail about how to actually use Django to create a data driven website. That’s what I’ll cover now. The goal for this ‘Getting Started’ project is to get familiar with the basics of developing data driven web applications using Django, Models, Views, Templates, URLs, and Forms. By the end we’ll have a simple contact form that saves user submissions to the database, and displays that data to an administrator user.

item.title: Configuring Vim When Using Git Bash on Windows
item.description: Occasionally I become enamored with the idea of becoming a Vim expert, or at least a competent Vim user. I work primarily in Windows environments so, though the desire exists, there aren’t many good opportunities to build Vim habits. There is a Vim on Windows release available. This has a GUI interface and an installer executable. Though if you have Git for Windows installed, then you already have Vim available.

item.title: MySQL Quick Reference
item.description: Shell Commands Set up security requirements: $ sudo mysql_secure_installation Open the MySQL CLI client and login using a password and the specified user: $ sudo mysql -u {user} -p MySQL Queries and Commands Note that MySQL will not execute anything until it encounters a semicolon ; which indicates the end of a statement. This allows us to enter multi-line statements. Create User > CREATE USER 'newuser'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password'; Give User Access to a Database > GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON * .

item.title: Gogs on Raspberry PI
item.description: In a previous article I configured a headless Raspberry Pi for Wifi and SSH. Next, I’ll set up a personal Gogs server on it. Change the Password First things first, change the password for the pi user to something different than raspberry. $ passwd Changing password for pi. (current) UNIX password: Enter new UNIX password: Retype new UNIX password: passwd: password updated successfully Please tweet your new password to @quakkels /s

item.title: Why I Prioritize Strength Training
item.description: Over the last few years, I’ve taken up a new hobby; strength training. It’s something I’ve really grown to love. Though, sometimes it’s hard to articulate exactly why strength training has taken such a permanent position in my weekly routine. When I was a sedentary person my quality of life decreased every year. Even when I was in my mid 20s I was not “strong” and frequent back and shoulder pain would frustrate me for weeks at a time.

item.title: Configure Headless Raspberry Pi for Wifi and SSH
item.description: Raspberry Pis are great little computers. Wonderful for running hobby services. But, whenever I start a new RPi project, I dislike needing to dig out my spare HDMI monitor and USB keyboard. I don’t like having to take up room and connect all that hardware to just enable SSH and Wifi which renders all that equipment unnecessary. Recently I learned how to flash a new micro SD card and configure it to connect to my Wifi network and enable SSH before even turning on the RPi for the first time.

item.title: Identify Valid Standards
item.description: I can’t tell you how many times I’ve been in software planning meetings when an engineer addressed the team and claimed that we should use {insert technology here} because it’s the “Industry Standard.” I also can’t tell you how many times I’ve done the same thing. I’ve gone into my boss’s office and claimed that we should use a particular stack or technology because it’s an “industry standard.” This reasoning is attractive because on the surface it seems valid.

item.title: Don't Take Frameworks for Granted
item.description: Frameworks can help jump-start productivity on projects. But be careful. Relying too much on frameworks could also limit yourself in the long run. Whenever the opportunity presents itself, programmers should carefully consider whether using a framework is beneficial. It may provide immediate benefits, but there should be no magic happening that isn’t understood by the programmer. Years ago, I learned how to make websites with C#. I had help from many books, tutorials, and co-workers.

item.title: Hello, I'm Brandon Quakkelaar
item.description: I believe that programming is a craft. My goal is to continuously study this craft, and to always refine my thinking and my execution while practicing it. I have a decade of experience and even though I have come a long way since I started, there’s always something fresh to study that I can add to my toolbox. Software development is a wonderful discipline that requires creativity, ingenuity, and logic.

item.title: Roast.it
item.description: Roast.it is a simple JavaScript unit testing library designed for providing a fast feedback loop with minimal fuss. There are no frills here. No unnecessary dependencies. This will run unit tests for you from npm test. It will not get in your way.

item.title: 5 Slack Tricks that Changed My Life
item.description: Please excuse the “click-baity” title. Sometimes I like to exaggerate. Slack plays a significant role in my daily communication. My team at work has been using Slack as our primary mode of textual communication for over a year. It is also used by developer communities in my local area. At first, it felt a little clumsy. No more clumsy than a typical chat program. But, channels started to accumulate. The number of Direct Message feeds grew.

item.title: Into the Nether: Linux
item.description: The first movie I saw that really got me excited about computers was WarGames. The WOPR was an inanimate object that just sat there on screen. But, it was still a complete character all by itself. It reacted to the Matthew Broderick character’s commands and questions and became something more clever than just a boring piece of hardware. The fictional software running inside the WOPR and Broderick’s character’s ability to interface with it created a story that was incredibly mystical and exciting.

item.title: Maintaining Your Vision
item.description: Programmers are often creators. Being a creator takes vision. Vision to see the destination, and vision to see the course. The destination could be learning a new language or technology stack. The destination could be a product to be released to customers. It could be something done for personal edification. The course is determined by taking that larger goal and breaking it down to manageable steps. The trick for successfully creating something, is to maintain that vision.

item.title: Let's Scrape the Web with Python 3
item.description: In the back of my mind I’ve always been intrigued by writing an application that can retrieve web pages over HTTP. It’s a fairly simple thing to do. We have a myriad of web browsers that do it for us. But there is just something about writing an application that operates independently of a browser and reaches out to touch the internet that I find fun and intriguing. So let’s do it… in Python.

item.title: What Happens When You Login?
item.description: Your favorite website is asking you for your username and password. Username? Password? Sure, you’ve got those. [You enter your username] then [you enter your password] then [you press enter] then boom, you’re logged into the website. What actually just happened? Well, assuming that you entered correct login credentials, you can now access whatever members only area that site offers to those credentials. But before that, in the split seconds after you clicked login and before you saw your profile, the website had to verify that the credentials you entered were correct.

item.title: Learn Insertion Sort with Video Game Discs
item.description: I think you could say I have an average number of video game discs. It’s not a huge number of games, but it is enough that it can be difficult to find a particular game if they’re not organized in a predictable way. Enter insertion sort. Insertion sort is in the same family as the bubble sort in that its worst case complexity is O(n2). But in practice, it is usually a faster sort.

item.title: Learn Bubble Sort with Playing Cards
item.description: Let’s say you have an unordered list of numbers and you wanted to put them in order from lowest to highest value. How would you do that? You’re probably thinking that you would just look at all the numbers, find the lowest number and put it at the beginning of your list. Then you would find the next largest number and put it in the second spot in the list, and so on until you’ve ordered the entire list of numbers.

item.title: Let's talk to a SQLite database with Python
item.description: As I write this, it’s the weekend. My wonderful wife brought home some amazing Jet Fuel XBold Dark Roast Coffee that is sure to keep me wired for the next several hours. Now what should I do? Let’s explore Python a little more by using it to talk to a database. We’re a long way from my bread and butter. My goto technologies for database interaction are .NET, C# and Entity Framework CodeFirst with SQL Server 2005⁄2008.

item.title: ASP.NET MVC Compared to Django
item.description: The MVC pattern is widely used in web development today. Regardless of whether you develop in C#, PHP, Python, Java, JavaScript, or Ruby, you won’t have any trouble finding a popular MVC pattern for your language of choice. Being primarily a C# developer, I’ve been using ASP.NET MVC since version 1. It’s a great framework. It can be very good at getting a project off the ground quickly, especially when coupled with a good ORM such as NHibernate, or Entity Framework.
